verses.verse: I'm an apostle aren't I? Am I not free? Haven't I seen Jesus Christ our Lord? Aren't you my work in the Lord?
If I am not an apostle to others, yet surely I am to you, for you are the seal of my apostleship by the Lord.
My answer to those who question me is this:
Don't we have the right to eat and drink?
Don't we have the right to lead around a sister, a wife, even as the other apostles and the brethren of the Lord and like Cephas?
Or is it only Barnabas and I who don't have the right to forego working for a living?
Who ever goes to war at his own expense? Who plants a vineyard and doesn't eat of its fruit? Or who feeds the flock and doesn't drink of the flock's milk?
Am I just talking like a man? Or doesn't the Law say the same thing also?
For it is written in the Law of Moses: "You shall not muzzle the ox's mouth that treads out the grain." Doesn't God have concern for oxen?
Or is He saying this for our sake? For our sake, no doubt, it is written: "He who plows should plow in hope," and "He who threshes in hope should be a partaker of his own hope."
If we have sown in you spiritual things, is it any great thing if we reap from you nonspiritual things?
If others partake of this right over you, shouldn't we have a greater right? Nevertheless, we haven't used this right, but suffer all things, lest we should hinder the gospel of Christ.
Don't you know that those who work around the holy things live [from the things] from the temple? And that those who serve at the altar, jointly share from the altar?
Even so the Lord has made arrangements that those who preach the gospel should make their living from the gospel.
But I haven't used any of these things, neither have I written these things that it should be done this way for me. For it would be better for me to die than for any one to void my rejoicing.
For though I preach the gospel, I have nothing to brag about, for I am compelled, yes woe is me if I don't preach the gospel.
For if I do this willingly, I have a reward, but if against my will, this responsibility is committed to me.
What is my reward then? [It is] that when I preach the gospel I can lay out the gospel of Christ without charge, so that I don't misuse my rights in the gospel.
For even though I am free from all, yet I have made myself a servant to all, so that I may win all the more.
To the Jews I became as a Jew, so that I might win the Jews; to those who under the Law, as under the Law, that I might win those who are under the Law.
To those who are without the Law, as one without the Law--not actually without God's law, but under the Christ's law--so that I might win those who don't have the Law.
To the weak I become as if I was weak, that I might win the weak. I become all things to all, so that I might by any means save some.
And I do this for the gospel's sake, that I might share of it with you.
Don't you know that those who run in a race all run but only one receives the prize? So run, that you may get it.
Every man contending for the victory is temperate in everything. Now they do it to obtain a corruptible crown but we an incorruptible.
Therefore I run, not with uncertainty; so I fight not like one who punches the air.
But I discipline my body and bring it under subjection, lest in any way after I have preached to others, I myself should be rejected.
